Charlie.Action: Was educated in Roman Catholic Parochial schools and one and a half years at a Jesuit college. Very intelligent and sharp sense of humor.
Raised sternly in the Roman Catholic tradition but now rejects many of the religion's tenets.
Always well dressed and fond of literature and films.
Often exchanges quotes from the New Testament with his friend Tony.
Speaks softly and confidentially in confession, shows personal reflection and an attempt to personalize his penance.
Joins in the mood of the group immediately, adapting quickly to social atmosphere.
Engages in casual justification of his thoughts and actions to God, indicating self-awareness but possible rationalization.
Attempts to hit a filled shot glass across the bar with a billiard stick but fails.
Tries to pull a tablecloth off a stranger's table without moving the glasses or bottles but fails.
Becomes obsessed and shouts to the stripper Diane, tossing things and calling her names, unable to control himself.
Sits alone watching Diane perform, reflects thoughtfully on racial differences, displaying some self-awareness and insight.
Responds to Michael's cigarette offer with polite acceptance and pays promptly.
Vouches for Johnny Boy's debts and assures Michael that Johnny will pay, despite not having clear control or certainty.
Remains silent when confronted about Johnny Boy avoiding Michael and payments, showing reluctance to engage or take responsibility.
Attempts to calm Michael with patronizing and confident talk to avoid escalation, showing some social skill but possibly overestimating control of situation.
Vouches for someone and promises to straighten him out.
Greets Johnny Boy warmly and interrupts with a friendly question.
Salutes and toasts with the group, calling out 'The queen!'
Shows concern by noticing and asking about Johnny Boy's face
Calmly participates in social banter, shows understanding by not questioning Johnny Boy’s story immediately.
Allows Johnny Boy to interrupt Michael, showing passivity in social interaction.
No actions, statements, or behaviors of Charlie are present in this excerpt to evaluate competence.
Nods in disbelief at Johnny Boy's story but quickly takes initiative to ask Tony for something to treat Johnny Boy's injury, showing practical problem-solving.
Reassures Tony and others by expressing belief and trust in Tony's claim about the panther ('Don't go to any trouble. We believe you... We believe you.')
Warns Tony to be careful with the panther
Warns Tony to be careful when opening the panther's cage.
Responds to Tony's threat casually by saying 'Don't go to any trouble. We believe you...'
Washes Johnny Boy's face with cold water, showing care despite the blood mixing in the water.
Makes half-joking, drunken remarks that criticize Tony's club and atmosphere, showing impatience and lack of tolerance.
Expresses desire for more lively, imaginative environment rather than accepting the ordinary, indicating a wish for engagement and spiritedness.
Jokes with the DRUNK and encourages him to go to the bathroom, causing laughter among the group.
Engages in playful banter with TONY and JOHNNY BOY, showing camaraderie but also coming off as pretentious and dismissive.
Makes a witty, confident joke to the drunk, lightening the mood and eliciting laughter.
Proposes a concept for a lively place with a creative name, showing imagination and confidence in his vision.
Engages in a playful argument with Tony and Johnny Boy, exhibiting social ease but little concrete progress or leadership.
Seems to wander over without clear purpose after making jokes, showing a lack of focus or initiative.
Encourages Jimmy after drawing a crude swastika, saying 'Not quite... but keep trying.'
Invites others to play a game, trying to engage the group despite refusals.
Shrugs and accepts lack of response from bar patrons after inviting them to play.
Drops cards in astonishment during violent shooting but takes cover with others instead of intervening.
Encourages Jimmy's drawing by saying 'Not quite... but keep trying.'
Attempts to organize a card game by inviting others, but is met with refusal and no response.
In reaction to a sudden violent shooting and struggle, he freezes and drops his cards out of astonishment.
Dashes behind tables and bar for cover along with others during the violent incident.
Asks Michael for a lift and allows Sammy, a very drunk and hysterical person, to crawl over him into the back seat without complaint.
Expresses frustration or exasperation ('Oh Jesus Christ...what's this.') upon Sammy's behavior.
Asks Michael for a lift promptly and gets into the car without hesitation, showing quick decision-making under pressure.
Expresses frustration with Sammy crying over him, indicating annoyance but no direct action to manage the situation or calm Sammy.
Expresses concern about Sammy's behavior and tries to keep the group calm by suggesting to 'get him in.'
Makes a sarcastic comment about Sammy and Johnny Boy hiding their faces from the young boy Sammy is shouting at.
Suggests slapping Johnny Boy to control the situation.
Expresses disbelief at Sammy's reckless behavior but does not intervene effectively.
Decides to be taken away from the neighborhood, showing awareness of danger.
Tries to get Sammy back inside after Sammy's disruptive outburst.
Allows Sammy's disruptive, childish behavior to continue without effective control.
Encourages Johnny Boy not to respond to Sammy's shouting, avoiding escalation.
Allows Johnny Boy to stay at his place when Johnny Boy is worried about going home looking disheveled and confirms his mother is not home.
Gets out of the car first with Johnny Boy to lead away from confrontation, showing situational awareness and initiative.
Tells Johnny Boy not to answer Sammy's shout, indicating good judgement and control over the situation.
Allows Johnny Boy to stay at his place without hesitation, showing reliability and social support.
Expresses 'Disgraceful' in reaction to others hiding their faces; brief and not elaborated, suggests some passivity or lack of deeper engagement.
Reassures his mother he will take care of things and tells her not to worry.
Advises Johnny Boy to be careful and reminds him that he is responsible for Johnny's debts.
Shows skepticism and a tough stance towards Johnny Boy's careless attitude about payment.
Reassures his mother that he will take care of everything and himself, showing responsibility and confidence.
Warns Johnny Boy about the consequences of messing up and insists on getting some payment to avoid bigger problems, demonstrating foresight and practical understanding.
Criticizes Johnny Boy's ability to handle problems, reflecting a clear assessment of others' capabilities which implies some situational awareness.
Confronts Johnny Boy assertively, setting clear expectations and threatening consequences to ensure compliance.
Keeps a firm control over the interaction, does not back down even when challenged.
Does not provide alternatives or negotiate beyond issuing threats, risk of escalating conflict.
Displays no hesitation or uncertainty in managing Johnny Boy, indicating confidence and control.
Hits Johnny Boy on the back of the head after an insensitive joke about Teresa's seizure and reprimands him to grow up and behave properly.
Goes to get a glass of milk quietly after Johnny Boy goes to bed, showing a calm, considerate demeanor.
Peers through the blinds at Teresa getting dressed, engaging in a secret affair.
Corrects Johnny Boy's immature behavior and tells him to grow up and handle things responsibly, such as asking for food properly.
Observes Teresa carefully through the window blinds, showing attentiveness and discreet behavior.
Goes to get a glass of milk calmly after Johnny Boy refuses food, indicating calmness and practical response.
Shakes his head with an exasperated smile at Johnny Boy's disturbance report, indicating tolerance of difficult situations.
Dreams of an intimate moment with Teresa where he experiences pain and distress, showing emotional sensitivity.
Agrees to go for lunch with Teresa and checks his wallet when she asks if he has enough money, demonstrating consideration and attentiveness.
Shakes his head with an exasperated smile at Johnny Boy's childish behavior, indicating awareness and restraint.
Checks his wallet before agreeing to go for lunch, showing practical awareness of his financial limits.
Dreams about a disturbing and confusing sexual experience, crying out in pain and showing emotional vulnerability.
Hesitates to take money from Teresa, showing modesty or pride.
Accepts money after Teresa insists and touches his face gently, allowing closeness.
Speaks hopefully about the future with Teresa, sharing plans and worries sincerely.
Gives Teresa a quick kiss on her nose, a tender, affectionate gesture.
Hesitates to accept money from Teresa but ultimately takes it; speaks cautiously about future plans, indicating some prudence and realism.
Gives Teresa a somewhat vague answer about apartment location ('Maybe, who knows') and expresses uncertainty about the future ('Nobody knows anything'), showing some lack of clarity or decisiveness.
Asks Teresa to find pamphlets on laws and by-laws relevant to businesses like restaurants and night clubs, demonstrating initiative and some planning behavior.
Responds 'Don't ask' when Teresa inquires further, which may indicate evasiveness or reluctance to share information fully.
Describes a chaotic and dangerous situation with vividness and recognition of fear, showing awareness and ability to assess events.
Takes Teresa in his arms to comfort her, telling her not to worry about her cousin breaking into her mother's house.
Reflects internally, acknowledging Teresa is a good kid and tries to justify his actions despite difficulties, showing a conflicted but sincere attitude.
Analyzes the kid's motivation and reputation strategy intelligently, showing insight into others' behavior.
Comforts Teresa confidently when she is upset, offering reassurance.
Engages in a self-reflective moment, acknowledging his own flaws realistically.
Expresses humility by comparing himself to the publican rather than the self-righteous Pharisee.
Swears he will not take advantage of a woman and will leave if she wants to marry someone else.
Critically points out poor service (dirty glass) to waitress, showing attentiveness to details but potentially coming off as fault-finding.
Critically examines the water spots on the glass and addresses the waitress to point out the dirt, indicating attention to detail and initiative to maintain standards.
Delivers religious references and moral justifications verbally, showing self-awareness but not directly demonstrating skill or effective action.
Critically examines water spots on glass and calls waitress to show her the dirt.
Engages in light, sympathetic conversation with Oscar, shaking his head in sympathy and laughing.
Refuses to take responsibility for informing Giovanni about Oscar's financial troubles, deflecting the burden.
Critically examines water spots on the glass and calls waitress to address cleanliness issue.
Listens to Oscar's problems and responds with appropriate sympathy and understanding.
Deflects responsibility to communicate loan payment issues to Giovanni rather than addressing it himself.
Asks where Groppi is, showing some awareness and concern about the situation.
Suggests Oscar speak directly to Giovanni about future plans, indicating a hands-off, possibly cautious approach but no direct problem solving or leadership.
Enters the cafe, greets people, shows familiarity and connection with the community and associates.
Politely interacts with repair man, thanks him for song request.
Passes by uncle and others unnoticed without any interaction.
Eavesdrops on private conversation by pretending to wash hands.
Eavesdrops on a private conversation by pretending to wash his hands and shutting off the faucet to listen carefully.
Asks repair man if his uncle is back there, showing awareness of surroundings and social connections.
Walks unnoticed past uncle and associates who are in a private conversation, indicating discretion.
Engages waitress Marie in a friendly, detailed monologue about coffee, showing interest in sharing his knowledge.
Continues talking about coffee despite waitress' disinterest, possibly showing self-centeredness or ignoring social cues.
Analyzes the coffee carefully, identifies approximate percentage of Colombian beans by taste.
Continues to explain in detail about the coffee and its origins confidently despite disinterest from waitress.
Over-explains coffee details to uninterested waitress, possibly showing a lack of social awareness.
Admits embarrassment and acknowledges his mistake to Giovanni
Offers help regarding Oscar's situation
Agrees to keep out of trouble and be careful
Insists on not calling in sick with Teresa to avoid suspicion
Encourages Teresa to take her time on the paper and says he doesn’t care about the timing
Admits he was embarrassed and confused something, showing awareness and willingness to acknowledge mistakes.
Offers to help with Oscar's business troubles, indicating proactiveness and sense of responsibility.
Agrees to keep out of trouble and be careful when instructed by Giovanni, showing compliance but also possibly lack of initiative or independence.
Refuses Teresa's suggestion to call in sick for work to avoid suspicion, demonstrating practical judgment and consideration of consequences.
Trying to read Henry James' Portrait of a Lady but quickly gives up calling it boring.
Tries to kiss Teresa but quickly loses interest and does not pursue her when she playfully turns away, causing confusion.
Points out the house of George Earhardt and expresses disdain with an insulting term, showing intolerance.
Gently accepts Teresa’s decision to take the apartment uptown and acknowledges her independence, showing some tolerance and support.
Feels embarrassed and nervous when his father responds oddly to Teresa's mother, showing sensitivity to social discomfort.
Shares a lighthearted moment with Teresa reflecting on his father's confused response.
Does not know how to react to his father's strange response, looks about nervously, shows embarrassment.
Attempts to rationalize or explain his father's odd statement with calm reasoning and humor.
Gets TERESA her medicine when she forgets it.
Crosses to TERESA and they kiss.
Confidently rings GROPPI's doorbell to conduct a survey despite being startled.
Refers to a notebook and compares addresses before approaching a cottage, demonstrating preparation and caution.
Confidently walks to the cottage door and rings the bell despite initial hesitation, showing some courage and decisiveness.
Stammers and awkwardly makes up excuses (selling encyclopedias, magazines, conducting a survey) when confronted unexpectedly, showing lack of quick thinking or social skill under pressure.
Is visibly startled and fails to maintain composure when the door is opened unexpectedly, indicating discomfort and lack of confidence in the situation.
Follows the boy who offers help to find Jack Groppi's place, despite uncertainty.
Continues to call out and tries to find his way out after being tricked by the boy.
Shares a humble confession about his misfortune ('Now, don't get excited.') and quotes scripture to comfort himself.
Enters the cafe and is warmly embraced by his uncle Giovanni; joins the friendly, boisterous social atmosphere.
Follows a boy who leads him into the forest but is ultimately abandoned, realizing he has been tricked and tries to find his way out.
Attempts to keep calm ('Now, don't get excited') and tries to recall a biblical quote to steady himself while lost, showing some mental resilience.
Smiles nervously and denies knowledge when questioned about a dangerous event involving Groppi, showing hesitation and possible fear rather than confident or skillful handling of the situation.
Waves back to Michael in a friendly manner when greeted at the cafe.
Speaks curtly to Michael in front of Giovanni, causing Michael to feel diminished.
Offers to meet later and proposes they all get together to 'knock some sense' into Johnny Boy, showing concern and willingness to help.
Responds to boys asking about firecrackers by directing them to Michael, avoiding involvement in illegal activity.
Does not attempt to sell or engage with the boys further, possibly indicating caution or lack of initiative.
Lets Michael and Tony into the car and engages with them to go to the movies, offers 'on you' to Michael.
Reflects sincerely about the upcoming party for his friend going to war, acknowledges it as a meaningful occasion.
Responds promptly when Tony calls him and gets in the car without hesitation, indicating readiness and attentiveness.
Asks for details about the $20 situation, showing awareness and a cautious approach to potential trouble.
Offers to go to the movies 'on you' in response to the money issue, showing social confidence and problem-solving in a lighthearted way.
Reflects on personal behavior with self-awareness, confessing he will likely get drunk at the party, showing insight but lack of self-control.
Expresses feeling sorry for someone with untapped talent, acknowledges their potential despite flaws.
Claims intellectual superiority and distinguishes between intelligent and stupid, dismisses others especially the army.
Reflects thoughtfully on the difference between intelligence and stupidity, acknowledges his own use of talent and brain.
Glues on a fake beard, preparing for a party, suggesting engagement but no clear indication of skill or confidence.
Compares himself to others intelligently and asserts his own capability confidently, despite not claiming genius.
Arrives at the party dressed as the resurrected Christ with arms outstretched, inviting interaction.
Arrives at the party dressed as resurrected Christ with white robes, fake beard and hair, and artificial wounds, making a striking entrance with arms outstretched.
Enters dressed as the resurrected Christ, playfully blessing everyone and engaging in a communal toast.
Playfully enacts a priest during the Mass ritual, fostering laughter and good spirits among friends.
Enters in mock holiness, confidently leads a playful ritual with wit and control of the group dynamic.
Engages in playful banter, skillfully improvises a script with Tony, keeping the mood lively and others entertained.

Shows concern and engagement in serious conversation with Michael.

Questions Michael about the original loan amount to understand the full scope of the problem.
Quotes biblical verses about loving enemies and giving to those who ask, tries to avoid harsh business reality.

Promises to save the sinner amid the chaos and rough behavior.

Walks through chaotic, rough behavior with a Christ-like manner, blessing others and attempting to impose calm and purpose.

Keeps calm and takes the others' blasphemous accusations and laughter in stride, responding with a forgiving line.
Responds to Teresa's worry with calm reassurance and tries to de-escalate her panic.
Sends Teresa away for her safety despite her reluctance.
Approaches a dangerous situation calmly, trying to communicate with Johnny Boy who is threatening with a gun.

Uses harsh language toward Johnny Boy and shows exasperation.

Clearly understands the urgent financial situation and communicates the seriousness of the loan and interest increase to Johnny Boy.

Shows anger and some rigidity in attitudes, possibly limiting flexible problem solving.

Openly admits his own lack of success or effective action in the situation.
Reacted with shock and pain after being shot and after Johnny Boy was hit; stayed on the scene holding his bleeding hand.

Sits on the curb in shock, muttering to himself, showing vulnerability and bewilderment after a traumatic event.

Sitting on the curb in shock, muttering to himself, bewildered after a car wreck.

Follows Mario outside without protest or visible assertiveness.
Listens and accepts the situation regarding being 'gotten out of jail' but then told he must be 'out of the way', shows passive compliance.
Declines Tony's offers of help, insists on handling his own money and writing home.
Responds irritably to Tony's questions and attempts to lighten mood.
States that he will handle his own finances and refuses help from Tony, indicating a degree of self-reliance and confidence.
